errors.simple: There's a syntax mistake in your code. This usually means missing brackets, quotes, or wrong indentation.
errors.fix:
Check line mentioned for:
• Missing closing brackets ) ] }
• Missing quotes ' or "
• Wrong indentation (Python needs consistent spaces)
• Missing colons : after if/for/def

errors.simple: Your code indentation is wrong. Python uses spaces to group code.
errors.fix:
Make sure all code blocks have consistent indentation:
• Use 4 spaces per level (not tabs)
• Check that all code in the same block is aligned
• After if/for/def/class, indent the next line

errors.simple: You're using a variable or function that doesn't exist yet.
errors.fix:
Check that you:
• Spelled the name correctly
• Defined it before using it
• Imported it if it's from a module
• Didn't accidentally delete or comment it out

errors.simple: You're trying to use something in the wrong way, like adding a string to a number.
errors.fix:
Check:
• Are you mixing strings and numbers?
• Are you calling something that's not a function?
• Did you pass the right number of arguments?
• Are you trying to modify an immutable type?

errors.simple: You're trying to access something that doesn't exist on this object, or the object is None.
errors.fix:
Common causes:
• Object is None - check if your function returned something
• Typo in attribute name
• Wrong object type
• Module not imported correctly

errors.simple: Python can't find the module you're trying to import.
errors.fix:
Try:
• pip install <module_name>
• Check if you spelled it correctly
• Make sure you're in the right virtual environment
• Check if the file exists if it's your own module

errors.simple: The module you want doesn't exist or isn't installed.
errors.fix:
Install it:
  pip install <module_name>

If it's your own module:
• Check the file name
• Make sure __init__.py exists in the folder
• Check your PYTHONPATH

errors.simple: You're trying to access an item that doesn't exist in the list.
errors.fix:
Check:
• Is your list empty?
• Are you using the right index number?
• Remember: Python counts from 0
• Use len(list) to check size first

errors.simple: You're trying to access a dictionary key that doesn't exist.
errors.fix:
Options:
• Check if key exists: if key in dict:
• Use get(): dict.get(key, default_value)
• Print dict.keys() to see what's available
• Check for typos in the key name

errors.simple: You're trying to convert something to the wrong type.
errors.fix:
Common issues:
• int('abc') won't work - can't convert text to number
• Check if string is actually a number
• Handle empty strings
• Use try/except for conversions

errors.simple: Python can't find the file you're trying to open.
errors.fix:
Check:
• Is the file path correct?
• Is the file in the right location?
• Use os.path.exists() to test
• Try absolute path: /full/path/to/file
• Check working directory: os.getcwd()

Add a check before dividing:
  if denominator != 0:
      result = numerator / denominator

Or handle with try/except

errors.simple: Your function is calling itself too many times.
errors.fix:
Add a base case:
  def func(n):
      if n <= 0:  # Base case
          return
      func(n-1)  # Recursive call

Or check if you need recursion at all
